Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Innovation and constraint: the evolution of power-amplified feeding in syngnathiform fishes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Syngnathiformes (seahorses, pipefishes, trumpetfish and relatives) are a group of fishes with unusual and novel modes of locomotion, reproduction, and feeding. Nearly all species are characterized by an elongated snout, which they rotate towards prey during feeding strikes. Recent research has shown that seahorses and pipefish are using power amplification to achieve extremely fast rotations, resulting in strikes that are among the fastest recorded for any fish (less than 2.5 milliseconds). This research will reconstruct the sequential evolutionary assembly of this mechanically extreme feeding mechanism and will investigate the consequences of this feeding mechanism on head shape diversity. The findings of this work will advance knowledge about how complex structure-function relationships evolve and influence subsequent structural evolution. The study will produce set of phylogenetic trees that reveal the evolutionary relationships among over 200 syngnathiform species. These will be a valuable resource and shared with other researchers to advance knowledge of the evolutionary history of this unique and unusual group of fishes. Other data and products from this research, including slow-motion videos, will engage a wide audience in the diversity of fish feeding strategies by incorporation into existing coursework at the University of California, Davis and through YouTube. In addition to forming an ambitious and integrative doctoral dissertation, this research will involve undergraduates interested in pursuing STEM related fields through hands-on training and experience.

This research will investigate the evolution of a mechanically extreme and complex feeding mechanism in syngnathiform fishes, beginning with the inference of a phylogeny using modern hybrid-enrichment (ultraconserved elements, UCEs) and next-generation sequencing technologies (Objective #1). Previous research has shown that seahorses and pipefish use power amplification to rotate their head towards prey faster than would be possible by direct muscle activation, and it has been proposed that this mechanism relies on a unique pivot joint in the skull. A combination of morphological and functional approaches including high-speed video, biomechanical modeling, and micro-CT scanning will be used to characterize and compare the feeding functional morphology of lineages related to seahorses and pipefish (Objective #2). The phylogeny from Objective #1 will be used to reconstruct the evolutionary history of the structural and functional changes necessary for power-amplified feeding in syngnathiform fishes and to test hypotheses about how the possession of this specialized mechanism has influenced the evolution of head shape in syngnathiforms (Objective #3). Models of continuous character evolution will to be fit to craniofacial shape data and compared in the software program OUwie to test the hypothesis that the possession of power amplification exerts strong stabilizing selection on craniofacial morphology. While the literature focuses on innovations that increase diversity, this work incorporates a model-testing approach to determine whether this novel feeding mechanism may constrain morphological diversification at macroevolutionary timescales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to examine the evolution of a novel and complex feeding mechanism within syngnathiform fishes (seahorses, pipefish, and their relatives) and to investigate how possession of this specialized mechanism has in turn fed back into this group’s morphological diversification. Our work has resulted in 3 peer-reviewed publications, a dissertation, published datasets, national conference presentations, and research experiences for undergraduate students.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Syngnathiform fish possess an elongated snout that they use in an unusual form of feeding called pivot feeding, whereby rapid upward head rotation brings the mouth close to prey. To understand how pivot feeding changes prey capture compared to other fishes, we developed a new approach to quantify the feeding strikes of over 40 species of fish. We found pivot feeding is an extreme form of feeding, allowing syngnathiforms to rely almost entirely on head movements rather than swimming or suction to get close to prey (Longo et al., 2016, Journal of Experimental Biology).

In addition to pivot feeding, pipefish and seahorses have been shown to use an elastic recoil mechanism (analogous to a slingshot) to achieve very fast feeding strikes by rotating their heads and snouts faster than should be possible by direct muscle activation. We have shown that another syngnathiform lineage, snipefish, also employs an elastic recoil mechanism to achieve fast feeding strikes. In addition we found that the geometry of their head creates a latch mechanism. In short, when components of the head are in a specific arrangement, the head does not rotate, so tendons can be loaded with elastic potential energy. When a trigger muscle changes the geometry of the head slightly, the tendon recoils and the head begins to rotate explosively. This work gives new insights into the origin of this novel functional system in syngnathiforms. It proves that elastic recoil is not unique to seahorses and pipefish, but may have evolved multiple times in parallel in lineages that were already pivot feeding with long snouts (Longo et al., 2018. Proceedings of the Royal Society B).

To inform our work syngnathiform fishes, we constructed the largest phylogenetic tree to date showing the evolutionary relationships for syngnathiforms and their relatives. We sequenced over 1,300 genetic markers (UCEs) from 113 species. We found strong support for the grouping of long-snouted syngnathiform families, which had been previously debated. We also found evidence consistent with an ancient rapid radiation leading to the origin of major syngnathiform lineages (Longo et al., 2017. Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution). Finally, we used our new phylogeny and a large morphological dataset for seahorses and pipefish to evaluate proposed trade-offs between snout dimensions based on the biomechanics of pivot feeding.

Broader Impacts:   

Sarah Longo (co-PI) conducted her dissertation research under this award, resulting in three first-author publications and seven presentations at local and national conferences. The project has resulted in substantial professional development for her through mentorship by the PI. Overall, this research has helped establish S. Longo as a young scientist conducting research at the intersection of evolution and biomechanics, with particular expertise working with elastic recoil mechanisms. She has been invited to participate in a symposium on this topic at the 2019 Society of Integrative and Comparative Biology, and is currently employed as a postdoc to study elastic recoil mechanisms. The skills that S. Longo has learned, including high-speed videography, biomechanical modeling, phylogenetic reconstruction, and comparative methods will continue to shape her academic career.

This grant provided opportunities for undergraduate students. Four undergraduates gained valuable research experience during this project, working with live animals and carrying out kinematic analyses. One is a coauthor on a publication. Datasets from this funded research, including high-speed videos, have also been incorporated into hypothesis-driven lab exercises for a vertebrate anatomy class at UC Davis. Students collect and analyze their own data and utilize prerequisites like math and physics for the study of biological systems. 

Seahorses and pipefish hold wide fascination in society, in large part due to their many unusual morphological and functional traits (male birth, loss of pelvic fins, upright posture, long snouts). Our work on their relatives helps put some of the traits of seahorses and pipefish into context, showing that perhaps they are not as novel as we thought. Or, on the flipside, that they actually belong to an entire clade of fish that also possess unusual traits that can fascinate and amaze. Our work on the evolution of pivot feeding and elastic-recoil in syngnathiform fishes serves as a case study for the evolution of complex functional traits. In addition, datasets and products from some of our papers have been published to online databases like NCBI Genbank and Dryad. Our genetic sequence data and phylogenetic trees in particular are a significant contribution to the wider community, providing a framework for future studies of syngnathiform fishes.
